key_insight: Terrain-following vertical coordinates can be made learnable and optimized end-to-end by differentiating through the atmospheric dynamical core, letting the model discover coordinate shapes that reduce grid-imprinted spurious motions instead of relying on fixed, hand-tuned decay scales.
problem_solved: Conventional terrain-following coordinates (hybrid, SLEVE, etc.) use analytic decay functions with heuristic scale parameters that are tuned by hand and can imprint distorted grid layers onto the solution, producing spurious horizontal and vertical motion over steep topography. The paper addresses automated discovery of coordinate definitions that minimize these errors.
method: Define a parametric family of vertical coordinate transforms (e.g., parameterized decay functions or spatially-varying scale maps) with learnable parameters.

Make the dynamical core differentiable and compute gradients of a chosen objective (e.g., metrics of spurious motion or forecast error) with respect to the coordinate parameters via automatic differentiation.
Optimize parameters end-to-end with regularization and physical constraints so learned coordinates reduce grid imprinting while preserving stability and conservation properties.
impact: Automating vertical-coordinate design reduces manual tuning, improves solution quality over complex terrain, and enables integrating coordinate optimization into data-driven or hybrid modeling workflows — accelerating development and improving accuracy for NWP and climate simulations.
visual_elements: Before/after schematic of vertical grid layers over steep topography: hand-tuned distorted layers vs. learned smoother layers
Side-by-side flow-field comparison (velocity/vertical motion) showing reduced spurious signals with learned coordinates
Training loop diagram: parametric transform → differentiable dynamical core → loss → autodiff gradients → parameter update
Plot of learned decay/scale functions or spatial parameter maps vs. traditional analytic profiles
paper_title: Learning vertical coordinates via automatic differentiation of a dynamical core
paper_authors: Tim Whittaker, Seth Taylor, Elsa Cardoso-Bihlo, Alejandro Di Luca, Alex Bihlo
